author: By Brian X. Chen
title: We’re Using A.I. Chatbots Wrong. Here’s How to Direct Them.
description: To mitigate the production and spread of misinformation from chatbots, we can steer them toward high-quality data.
content: Anyone seduced by A.I.-powered chatbots like ChatGPT and Bard — wow, they can write essays and recipes! — eventually runs into what are known as hallucinations, the tendency for artificial intelligence to fabricate information.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brandon Shimoda and Anne Boyer
title: Poem: The Desert
description: Brandon Shimoda wrote this short poem after encountering a lost migrant in the Arizona desert.
content: “The Desert,” from Brandon Shimoda’s new collection, “Hydra Medusa,” is emblematic of the complex lyric-historical landscape of borders, dreams, shrines and underworlds found throughout his work. I asked Shimoda about the context and composition of this poem, and his answer was a skillful, evocative illumination of the relationship between life and poetry: “I wrote this poem the night after going out on a water drop with a humanitarian-aid group. We drove for many hours through the desert, putting water out for migrants, people trying to stay alive. We met a man who, in the hallucinatory heat of Arizona, asked how far it was to Kentucky. Some important part of an individual exists in the places they are trying to reach, and it is excruciating. It is like we are following the signs and symbols of our future selves through the wilderness. I write poetry when I am feeling haunted by something — an image, encounter — although not as a means of exorcism. I think about what I have seen, heard, experienced, and I go under. I write poetry at night, partly because I believe there is a more humane, trustworthy logic to be found there, although like dreams, and like the landscapes in which they graze, the poems are themselves the interpretation.” Selected by Anne Boyer
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Yuhas
title: On the Map, Nothing. On the Ground, a Hidden Maya City.
description: In a biological preserve in Mexico’s Campeche State, a team of archaeologists has documented pyramids, palaces, a ball court and other remains of an ancient city they call Ocomtún.
content: Armed with machetes and chain-saws, hacking through fallen trees and wading through dense scrub, the archaeologists cleared a path down rocky trails.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Ukrainian Children With Cancer Fight Their Own War Within a War
description: The war with Russia compounds the struggles of pediatric cancer patients and their families, but it has also prompted positive changes in treatment in Ukraine.
content: Eighteen-month-old Mykola clutched his mother’s finger as he toddled up the hallway of the national children’s hospital in Kyiv, his still-unsteady legs eager to keep up with his desire to walk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: ‘While We Watched’ Review: A Lament and a Battle Cry
description: This documentary about the veteran broadcast journalist Ravish Kumar is less an inspiring tale than a wake-up call for India.
content: In the opening moments of Vinay Shukla’s documentary “While We Watched,” its subject, the veteran Indian news anchor Ravish Kumar, stands in a partly demolished building and wonders, “When you find yourself all alone, whom do you listen to?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: Hoping for a Miracle, Hurtling Toward Disaster
description: Are we doomed to witness the Trump-Biden rematch nobody wants?
content: Have you met anyone truly excited about Joe Biden running for re-election? And by that, I mean downright Obama-circa-2008 energized — brimming with enthusiasm about what four more years of Biden would bring to our body politic, our economy, our national mood, our culture?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Carlin Glynn, Actress Whose Comeback Brought Her a Tony, Dies at 83
description: After putting her career on hold to raise children, she won the part of the madam in “The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas” — and then a statuette hailing her performance.
content: Carlin Glynn, a stage actress who, after a long hiatus spent raising a family, stepped back into the footlights, sang onstage for the first time and walked away with a Tony Award for her performance as the madam in the 1978 hit “The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas,” died on July 13 at her home in upstate New York, in the Hudson Valley. She was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Dick Biondi, Fast-Talking Star of Top 40 Radio, Dies at 90
description: “Wild, outrageous, goofy and uplifting,” as one fan put it, he was based in Chicago for most of his career but had fans all over the country.
content: Dick Biondi, an exuberant, fast-talking Top 40 radio personality, nicknamed “the Screamer,” who in the early 1960s became one of Chicago’s most popular disc jockeys and, thanks to the strength of his station’s signal, was heard well beyond the city, died on June 26 in Chicago. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 20, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, July 20, 2023.
content: An article on Wednesday about a House measure pledging support for Israel misstated the day that Representative Rashida Tlaib of Michigan gave an emotional speech on the House floor. She spoke on Tuesday, not Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Senate Panel Approves Supreme Court Ethics Bill With Dim Prospects
description: Republicans accused Democrats of trying to undermine the court with the measure and vowed to block it from advancing in the Senate, making it highly unlikely to become law.
content: The Senate Judiciary Committee on Thursday approved legislation that would impose strict new ethics rules on justices, moving over fierce objections from Republicans to address a string of revelations about Supreme Court justices taking free luxury trips and receiving other financial benefits from wealthy benefactors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Kolker
title: The Vanishing Family
description: They all have a 50-50 chance of inheriting a cruel genetic mutation — which means disappearing into dementia in middle age. This is the story of what it’s like to live with those odds.
content: Barb was the youngest in her large Irish Catholic family — a surprise baby, the ninth child, born 10 years after the eighth. Living in the suburbs of Pittsburgh, her family followed the football schedule: high school games on Friday night, college games on Saturday, the Steelers on Sunday. Dad was an engineer, mom was a homemaker and Barb was the family mascot, blond and adorable, watching her brothers and sisters finish school and go on to their careers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Ukraine starts using American-made cluster munitions in its counteroffensive, U.S. officials say.
description: The weapons are being used in the southeast, the officials say.
content: Ukrainian forces have started using American-made cluster munitions against Russia’s defensive positions, two United States military officials said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: Kenya Stares Into ‘Abyss’ as Soaring Prices and Feuding Leaders Bring Chaos
description: Antigovernment protests over price hikes and new taxes have left at least 31 people dead in recent weeks, prompting the country’s news outlets to join together to issue a dire warning.
content: Kenya’s boisterous news outlets are normally fierce rivals. But on Thursday they set aside their competitive instincts to issue an urgent appeal for calm as Kenya plunged deeper into chaotic anti-government demonstrations that have left at least 31 people dead in recent weeks and present the gravest challenge yet to the nearly year-old rule of President William Ruto.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Airlines Are Thriving as People Keep Traveling
description: Three large U.S. airlines have reported strong quarterly sales and profits in recent days because of strong demand, high fares and relatively low fuel prices.
content: Summer travel is off to a roaring start, with little sign of a slowdown on the horizon. And airline executives say they are doing all they can to keep up, including contending with bad weather and congestion in the skies and on the ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: Russia Targets Ukraine’s Ports, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Is Where Paranoia Meets Legacy Admissions
description: R.F.K. Jr. and Trump belong to a new breed of arrogant oxymorons.
content: It feels dangerous to write about Robert F. Kennedy Jr.: In the lag between when I put the finishing touches on this and when it becomes publicly available, I could be a conspiracy theory or two behind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: This Heat Wave Has Become Dangerous for the Elderly
description: Also, the Women’s World Cup begins. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
content: An onslaught of heat waves — across the Southern U.S., as well as much of Europe and the Middle East — have elevated average global temperatures to historic highs. Extended exposure to the sweltering heat can be a potential health risk for anyone, particularly those who do outdoor work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang Che
title: Jury Awards $800,000 to a Girl Burned by a Chicken McNugget
description: The 7-year-old deserved to be compensated by McDonald’s for a second-degree burn caused by a wayward piece from a Happy Meal when she was 4, a Florida jury decided this week.
content: A Florida jury awarded $800,000 in damages to a 7-year-old girl on Wednesday for the suffering and mental anguish caused when a Chicken McNugget fell on her thigh, causing a second-degree burn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea Stays Silent on U.S. Soldier Who Fled Into the Country
description: It may take days or weeks for the country to acknowledge that it has Pvt. Travis T. King in custody, and past practices suggest its response will be determined by Mr. King’s motive.
content: North Korea has not yet responded to the mystery surrounding a United States Army private’s  decision to flee across the inter-Korean border on Tuesday, and it may not ​comment on the case for days, or even months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: Biden Administration Moves to Raise the Cost of Drilling on Federal Lands
description: The royalty rates paid by oil, gas and coal companies for the right to drill and mine on land owned by the public have not changed since 1920.
content: The Biden administration on Thursday proposed a rule that would raise the royalties that fossil fuel companies pay to pull oil, gas and coal from public lands for the first time since 1920, while increasing more than tenfold the cost of the bonds that companies must pay before they start drilling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Dowling
title: ‘The Venture Bros.: Radiant Is the Blood of the Baboon Heart’ Review: Return of the Glorious Weirdos
description: A beloved Adult Swim cartoon comes back to tie up some loose ends.
content: Over seven seasons on Adult Swim, the Cartoon Network’s nighttime programming block, “The Venture Bros.” brought to the small screen a fantastical world steeped in absurdist humor, rooted in pop culture and presented in the style of old-time cartoon adventures. Within this exemplar of animated brain candy dwelled a host of glorious weirdos: chief among them, Dr. Thaddeus Venture (voiced by James Urbaniak), a man-child flailing in his superscientist father’s shadow; his goofy, fatality-prone sons, Hank (Chris McCulloch, a.k.a. Jackson Publick) and Dean (Michael Sinterniklaas), whose demises were easily remedied by a basement full of clones; their sex-and-death-machine bodyguard, Brock Samson (Patrick Warburton); and Dr. Venture’s equally petulant frenemesis, the Monarch (Publick), and his gravelly-voiced bombshell wife, Dr. Mrs. the Monarch (Doc Hammer).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: With Aaron Rodgers, Jets Enter Era of Expectation
description: Adding Rodgers, the star quarterback, to a team with young talent and a strong defense has players eyeing the Super Bowl. It is a big jump for a franchise that has missed the past 12 postseasons.
content: For a brief moment on Thursday, Aaron Rodgers and the Jets showed everyone what rejuvenation looks like.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: The Perpetual Stew Is More About Community Than Cuisine
description: Annie Rauwerda has been cooking a stew in her Brooklyn apartment for over a month. Its flavor changes with the ingredients people bring to tasting events at a park in Bushwick.
content: They wore floppy toques and were flanked by an array of ingredients: vegetable broth, chili peppers, bay leaves, potatoes, shallots, radishes, garlic powder, canned beans, carrots and more — all crowdsourced from their eager guests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Mestre-Reed
title: A Test of the American Dream, Set in a Leprosy Ward
description: In her debut novel, “King of the Armadillos,” Wendy Chin-Tanner explores immigration, illness and opportunity through the story of a teenage immigrant who is diagnosed with Hansen’s disease.
content: When Hans Castorp arrives at the tuberculosis sanitarium in Davos-Platz, Switzerland, in “The Magic Mountain” — Thomas Mann’s monumental meditation on the metamorphosing process of illness, the mutability of time and the feast of death that is the human body — he thinks he’s there for a three-week visit. His short stay transforms into a seven-year passage through all the stages of the human tragicomedy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Suhasini Raj
title: Video of Sexual Assault Goes Viral in India, Renewing Attention on Ethnic Conflict
description: The attack on two women in the state of Manipur led to the first public comments from Prime Minister Narendra Modi, however indirect, about the monthslong violence in the state.
content: It took more than two months for word of the shocking sexual assault to spread, partly because the internet in the region had been shut down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson and Jenny Vrentas
title: N.F.L. Fines Snyder $60 Million for Sexual Harassment and Withholding Revenue
description: Daniel Snyder will pay $60 million in restitution after a league investigation found that he sexually harassed a female employee and improperly withheld revenue when he owned the Washington Commanders.
content: Daniel Snyder was fined $60 million, by far the largest penalty ever levied against an N.F.L. team owner, after he was found to have sexually harassed a woman who was both a former cheerleader and a marketing employee for the Washington Commanders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Vognar
title: In ‘Twisted Metal’ Series, Killer Clowns Come With Class Commentary
description: Peacock’s new show indulges in the same ultraviolence as the video game that inspired it. But this time it has a message about the haves and the have-nots.
content: When Stephanie Beatriz likes a script she enjoys reading it aloud at home to get a better feel for the character and story. She warmed up quickly to “Twisted Metal,” the new Peacock mayhem machine based on the popular PlayStation game series that first burned rubber in 1995. But as she turned the pages, encountering psycho clowns, murderous religious cults, cannibalism and other manner of good times, she had to pause. Her 8-month-old daughter was in the room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Ponzi Schemer Freed From Prison by Trump Faces New Fraud Charges
description: Eliyahu Weinstein, whose 24-year sentence President Donald J. Trump commuted, is now accused of bilking 150 people out of more than $35 million.
content: A convicted Ponzi schemer, whose prison sentence President Donald J. Trump commuted in one of his last official White House acts, is facing new fraud federal charges of bilking investors in a series of phony deals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: New Zealand’s Fruit-Rich Ice Cream Gets a Sugary American Makeover
description: The wholesome summer favorite is catching on in the U.S., but with sprinkles, drizzles and even cookies to satisfy the nation’s sweet tooth.
content: In New Zealand, one of summer’s great pleasures is known as real fruit ice cream: a scoop of vanilla blended with fruit in a machine that produces an airy, barely sweet twirl with a buttery texture. The dessert, which likely originated in the country’s berry orchards, has become a national favorite over the last few decades, prized for its freshness and simplicity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Reports of a Lioness Near Berlin Prompt a Sprawling Search
description: People were encouraged to stay home after the police received calls and a video of a wild cat believed to be a lioness in a town along the German capital’s southwest boundary.
content: The Berlin bear was given a run for its money as the official symbol of Germany’s capital on Thursday. The authorities said that a “free-roaming lioness” in the area had led to a sprawling search with more than 100 police officers, veterinarians and hunters as well as drones and helicopters involved in trying to catch the animal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Omar G. Encarnación
title: Spain Is Going to Be Absolutely Fine
description: Sunday’s election will determine the country’s political direction, not the fate of its democracy.
content: A choice between democracy and autocracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘The Deepest Breath’ Review: A Perilous Drop Into the Ocean
description: Astonishing underwater footage elevates this documentary about two people drawn to the extreme sport of free diving.
content: While watching “The Deepest Breath,” a documentary that palpably conjures the mystery and menace of the deep sea, I found it difficult not to think of the Titan submersible disaster last month. But this film, on Netflix, invites viewers to submerge alongside thrill-seekers unconfined by a vessel: Its subject is the extreme sport of free diving, in which competitors plunge into the depths for minutes at a time without scuba gear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Miller
title: The Strange Unseriousness of No Labels
description: Many Americans fear a second Trump term and are dissatisfied. No Labels is here to take advantage of that sadness with a half-finished idea.
content: GOFFSTOWN, N.H. — “I’m not afraid of losing,” Senator Joe Manchin said, with some real charm and conviction, on Monday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced
title: Blackstone Becomes First $1 Trillion Private Equity Manager
description: Passing that milestone puts the firm in the same league as mutual fund behemoths and banking giants.
content: For years, private equity firms have sought to join a special club: managing $1 trillion in assets, a milestone that would put them in the same league as mutual fund behemoths like BlackRock and Fidelity and banking giants like JPMorgan Chase.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: This Summer, Pause for the Vermouth Hour
description: Good vermouth makes a great aperitif, fueling a delightful transitional moment before a meal.
content: Earlier this year while in Madrid, I fell prey to what the Spanish call la hora del vermut, the vermouth hour, a break in the day for a glass, generally before eating. In Spain it customarily takes place before lunch. On my visit, though, I saw more people pausing for vermouth after the workday, as a transitional moment before embarking on whatever adventures the evening promised.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Mancuso and Alicia Napierkowski
title: Homes for Sale in Connecticut and New York
description: This week’s properties are a four-bedroom in Redding, Conn., and a three-bedroom in Rye, N.Y.
content: A four-bedroom, three-and-a-half-bath, 4,527-square-foot, expanded home built in 1910, with original stone walls and archways, hardwood flooring and wood beams; a cozy foyer preceded by a screen porch entryway; a great room with wood paneling and a fireplace; a kitchen with banquet seating; a bright dining room with wood shelving; a sunroom with floor-to-ceiling windows and a slider that leads to a stone patio; a step-down formal living room with built-in bookshelves and a bay window; an office alcove and lounging rooms; an en suite primary bedroom with a sitting area and a skylight; a landscaped yard with an in-ground pool, flower gardens, a stream, a barn and a detached two car garage with a guest apartment on 15.9 acres. Roni Agress, 203-733-2656; William Pitt Sotheby’s International, williampitt.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Delger Erdenesanaa
title: Signature Biden Program Won’t Fix Racial Gap in Air Quality, Study Suggests
description: The White House aimed for a race-neutral environmental justice strategy, but a new analysis questions whether the program can actually achieve its goals.
content: A new analysis has found that the White House’s signature environmental justice program may not shrink racial disparities in who breathes the most polluted air, in part because of efforts to ensure that it could withstand legal challenges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: Kevin Mitnick, Once the ‘Most Wanted Computer Outlaw,’ Dies at 59
description: Best known for an audacious hacking spree in the 1990s involving the theft of data and credit card numbers, he later became a security consultant and public speaker.
content: Kevin Mitnick, who at the dawn of widespread internet usage in the mid-1990s became the nation’s archetypal computer hacker — obsessive but clever, shy but mischievous and threatening to an uncertain degree — and who later used his skills to become “chief hacking officer” of a cybersecurity firm, died on Sunday in Pittsburgh. He was 59.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Lynsea Garrison, Diana Nguyen, Nina Feldman, Patricia Willens, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto, Chelsea Daniel and Alyssa Moxley
title: The Man Trying to Save Phoenix From Historic Heat
description: The city is attempting to adapt to a new reality of extreme heat waves.
content: As a historic heat wave grips much of the world and the United States, no city has become more emblematic of the crisis than Phoenix, where temperatures have exceeded 110 degrees for the past three weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: 6-Year-Old Suffocated and Bus Monitor Didn’t Notice, Prosecutor Says
description: The girl, who was unable to speak, was in a wheelchair at the back of the bus, and the monitor had her earbuds in. A New Jersey prosecutor charged the woman with manslaughter.
content: Amanda Davila, a 27-year-old school bus monitor, was sitting toward the front of her bus on Monday morning, focused on her cellphone and wearing her earbuds. Several rows back was one of the children she was supposed to keep an eye on: a disabled 6-year-old girl in a wheelchair who was unable to speak, on her way to a summertime education program in New Jersey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Considine
title: ‘Return to Dust’ Review: Grit Against All Odds
description: Li Ruijun’s newest feature is a touching portrait of love and resiliency that doubles as a critique of China’s ruling class.
content: According to reliable news reports, the Chinese government never confirmed having banned Li Ruijun’s quietly heartbreaking feature “Return to Dust,” a touching portrait of love and resiliency in a collapsing rural community of Gansu Province.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
title: A Collision in Court: Trump Grand Jury Proceedings Delay a Jan. 6 Verdict
description: A defense lawyer was late. A judge grew irked. Prosecutors were hauled out of a grand jury. It was an example of the complexities stemming from the multiple proceedings involving Donald Trump.
content: For several months, Federal District Court in Washington has been ground zero for the Justice Department’s various attempts to deal with the legacy of former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Theme Park’s Selective History Appeals to a New Spanish Nationalism
description: Puy du Fou España has drawn visitors with spectacular shows about Spanish history. But part of its success lies in what goes unsaid.
content: Moving through the darkened holds of a replica of Christopher Columbus’s ship, visitors on a recent afternoon marveled at the tangle of compasses, cordage and barrels. They stumbled as the ship swang and creaked with the swell of the sea. At last, a voice shouted “Land!” and the white sands of America appeared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Wheat prices remain high as concern grows about Black Sea instability and disruption to the grain supply.
description: There’s a robust supply of grain globally, but a long-term disruption to exports from Ukraine and a reliance on fewer countries for grain could cause prices to become more volatile.
content: As Black Sea-bound vessels clustered in the waters near Istanbul, wheat prices remained elevated on Thursday, up 13 percent since Monday, when Russia pulled out of a wartime agreement that had been considered critical to stabilizing global food prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christian Lorentzen
title: A Novel of Sex and Crisis in the Aftermath of the 1960s
description: Henry Bean’s first novel, reissued as “The Nenoquich,” follows a young writer in Berkeley through a transformative affair.
content: Cynicism, laziness, anger, misplaced righteousness, vacillation between vanity and self-loathing: Such are the qualities of the superfluous men we’ve encountered in novels for centuries. Existing somehow outside the structures of family and regular employment, these prodigal sons have too much time on their hands — time to spend thinking, ranting, writing or intoxicating themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Friday Briefing: The First Wins in the Women’s World Cup
description: Also, tensions between Iraq and Sweden and a gathering of golden retrievers.
content: The first matches of the Women’s World Cup showcased the growth and promise of women’s soccer — but also some of the sport’s persistent challenges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: How TV Writing Became a Dead-End Job
description: The writers say Hollywood studios are increasingly limiting their roles in television productions, highlighting a trend for white-collar workers.
content: For the six years he worked on “The Mentalist,” beginning in 2009, Jordan Harper’s job was far more than a writing gig. He and his colleagues in the writers’ room of the weekly CBS drama were heavily involved in production. They weighed in on costumes and props, lingered on the set, provided feedback to actors and directors. The job lasted most of a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Buchanan
title: Catch Them if You Can
description: Corbin Carroll changed everything for Arizona and Elly De La Cruz has revitalized Cincinnati. The phenoms, and their contending teams, face off this weekend.
content: Midway through last season, Zac Gallen, the ace right-hander of the Arizona Diamondbacks, found himself surveying the baseball landscape. Everywhere he looked, terrific young players were remaking the game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Betts
title: Missouri Supreme Court Allows Abortion Ballot Initiative to Move Ahead
description: The effort to put abortion rights before voters was held up when the attorney general said the state auditor had vastly underestimated the potential cost to taxpayers.
content: The Missouri Supreme Court ruled against the state attorney general’s position on an abortion ballot initiative, a decision that allows an effort to restore abortion rights there to move forward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: Upstate Art Weekend Is Bigger Than It’s Ever Been
description: A great getaway awaits you up the Hudson: An annual festival of more than 100 participants across 10 New York counties, including NADA Foreland.
content: In just three years, Upstate Art Weekend has grown from an informal map for visiting city folk to an annual festival of more than 100 participants across 10 New York counties. At this weekend’s fourth edition, you’ll be able to wander through private artists’ studios at the Poughkeepsie Underwear Factory, Beacon Open Studios or Newburgh’s Atlas Studios; bid in an auction supporting the New York Abortion Access Fund at Noise for Now in Kingston; even preview a Borscht Belt Museum set to open in Ellenville in 2025. And then there are the performances: On Friday, the Hudson Valley Intertribal Noise Symposium brings a lineup of Indigenous sound artists to the idyllic sculpture park at Art Omi, and on Saturday, the CCS Bard Hessel Museum of Art hosts an outdoor performance by Emily Johnson in conjunction with its show “Indian Theater: Native Performance, Art and Self-Determination Since 1969.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Martha Saxton, Historian Who Explored Women’s Lives, Dies at 77
description: Her wide range of subjects included the actress Jayne Mansfield, the novelist Louisa May Alcott and Mary Washington, the mother of a president.
content: Martha Saxton, a historian whose penetrating examinations of women’s lives led her to new insights into figures ranging from the author Louisa May Alcott to the 1950s actress and sex symbol Jayne Mansfield to Mary Washington, the mother of the first president of the United States, died on Tuesday at her home in Norfolk, Conn. She was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Matthew Goldstein
title: Inside the Private Writings of Caroline Ellison, Star Witness in the FTX Case
description: Ms. Ellison, a top executive in Sam Bankman-Fried’s business empire, recorded her thoughts on private Google documents that offer new insight into the collapse of the FTX crypto exchange.
content: Three months before the cryptocurrency market imploded last year, Caroline Ellison, the 27-year-old chief executive of the crypto hedge fund Alameda Research, was racked with self-doubt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Streetwise’ Review: A Bleak Upbringing in a Brutal Town
description: In Na Jiazuo’s striking directorial debut, young people inhabit a place seemingly made up of those who owe money and the thugs who try to beat it out of them.
content: This consistently striking and deeply sad picture is the directorial feature debut of Na Jiazuo, who executes it with an assurance that makes him more than merely promising. The story is set in 2004, in a town within China’s Sichuan Province where not much is going on, it seems, besides criminality and tattooing. Oh, yes, the local hospital is pretty busy, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Healy
title: The Most Essential Worker in a Heat Wave? The A.C. Guy
description: While trying to cool brutally hot Phoenix, Roberto Guerrero and his sons endure sweltering attics, blazing rooftops and nonstop calls for help.
content: José Guerrero’s phone buzzes from morning to midnight with sweaty pleas for help: The air-conditioner fan just quit. My grandma is stuck in a 90-degree house. My children are overheating. Please come, it’s so hot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: New York’s Moldiest Neighborhoods
description: A recent study tracked mold complaints in the city over the last six and a half years. So where is mold the worst?
content: There are household nightmares, and then there’s mold. Getting rid of mold can be expensive and disruptive. Even worse, according to the World Health Organization, mold can trigger allergic reactions, aggravate asthma and release the mycotoxins that can cause acute poisoning. Mold is also linked to serious diseases like cancer and disorders like immune deficiency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: More Visible L.G.B.T.Q. People Isn’t a Curiosity or a Crisis — It’s Normal
description: The increase in the number of visible gay and trans people is sometimes treated as a curiosity or a cause for concern by critics, but it’s not a surprise. It’s normal.
content: What’s the correct number of lesbians? Gay men? Bisexuals? Trans people? Is there a number that is too high? Too low? Just right?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Trump’s Legal Woes Mount as Trial Dates and Campaign Calendar Collide
description: The Republican front-runner is facing a growing tangle of criminal and civil trials that will overlap with next year’s presidential primaries.
content: As former President Donald J. Trump campaigns for the White House while multiple criminal prosecutions against him play out, at least one thing is clear: Under the laws of physics, he cannot be in two places at once.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Tiered Work Forces
description: The rise of piecemeal work is a key issue in the Hollywood writers’ strike.
content: Universities devote a smaller share of faculty slots to tenured professorships than in the past — and hire more adjunct professors who have little chance for promotion. Law firms employ relatively fewer partners and more lawyers who are paid less. And Hollywood hires fewer writers to participate in the entire production process, relegating more of them to piecemeal work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: What Russia’s Grain Deal Actions Mean for Ukraine
description: Moscow withdrew from a deal that allowed Ukraine to export grain across the Black Sea despite a wartime blockade, and warned that ships sailing around Ukrainian ports would be seen as military targets.
content: Russia warned on Wednesday that it would consider any ship sailing around Ukrainian ports a military target, days after Moscow pulled out of a yearlong deal that had enabled Kyiv to export its grain across the Black Sea despite a wartime blockade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: ‘They Cloned Tyrone’ Review: There’s Only One John Boyega
description: In Juel Taylor’s imaginative sci-fi movie, Boyega teams up with Jamie Foxx and Teyonah Parris to find the forces undermining their community.
content: “They Cloned Tyrone,” an ambitious, nightmarish tale about unsettled identity, opens with an image of two blue eyes, strained at the corners. The camera pulls back, revealing the owner of those peepers to be a grinning white man on a billboard with the tagline “Keep em’ smiling.” In front of the advertisement, Black people debate possible sightings of Tupac Shakur and Michael Jackson, now allegedly disguising himself with new Black skin. The food mart, with the billboard prominently displayed by its door, is where these gossiping Black folk hold court, and is one of the many institutions that dot the neglected, fictional urban landscape its residents refer to as the Glen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Beggs
title: The Shows May Be Over. But John Mayer’s ‘Guitar Face’ Lives On.
description: For some fans of Dead & Company, which just finished its Final Tour, the faces made by John Mayer while performing are almost as memorable as the music.
content: During the final show of Dead & Company’s so-called Final Tour on Sunday night, the crowd at Oracle Park in San Francisco swayed and bobbed like the current of a turning river.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Bamberger
title: The Joys of Links Golf Never Get Old
description: No matter which seaside, windswept course hosts the British Open, the final major tournament of the year puts a golfer’s imagination to work, and captures ours.
content: Tired of the whole golf-gone-wild thing? The one that has turned the men’s professional game into a new toy for Saudi investors? The one that has U.S. senators dragging golf (minus the bag) to work? The one that has left the PGA Tour star Rory McIlroy saying he feels like a sacrificial lamb in the proposed PGA Tour-LIV Golf partnership?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: Building a Legal Wall Around Donald Trump
description: American legal institutions have passed the Jan. 6 test so far, but the tests aren’t over.
content: The American legal system is on the cusp of a remarkable historical achievement. In real time and under immense pressure, it has responded to an American insurrection in a manner that is both meting out justice to the participants and establishing a series of legal precedents that will stand as enduring deterrents to a future rebellion. In an era when so many American institutions have failed, the success of our legal institutions in responding to a grave crisis should be a source of genuine hope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin and Nico Grant
title: Google Tests A.I. Tool That Is Able to Write News Articles
description: The product, pitched as a helpmate for journalists, has been demonstrated for executives at The New York Times, The Washington Post and News Corp, which owns The Wall Street Journal.
content: Google is testing a product that uses artificial intelligence technology to produce news stories, pitching it to news organizations including The New York Times, The Washington Post and The Wall Street Journal’s owner, News Corp, according to three people familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Capturing a 21st-Century War With 19th-Century Technology
description: Edward Kaprov’s wet-plate technique is producing some of the most memorable and timeless photographs of the war in Ukraine close up.
content: The news coverage from Ukraine has been so intense and widespread over the past 16 months that it may seem that the war has been covered to the point of saturation. Yet for all the wealth of film and photographs to come out of the war, there have been significant gaps, most notable a shortage of combat photography.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Quick to Mock MAGA, Biden Stays Silent on Trump Indictments
description: The president has taken swipes at Republicans, including a video playfully featuring Marjorie Taylor Greene as a narrator, but he and his allies are avoiding one target: his predecessor’s legal woes.
content: For months, President Biden has appeared to delight in needling Donald J. Trump and his Republican allies, trying at every turn to make MAGA and ultra-MAGA a shorthand for the entire party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Chart Topper
description: Drew Schmenner takes on Thursday puzzle trickiness.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Neil MacFarquhar and James C. McKinley Jr
title: As Russia Steps Up Attacks on Grain Ports, U.S. Warns of Possible Ruse
description: A White House official said Moscow might stage an attack on a commercial ship and blame Ukraine.
content: Russia on Thursday stepped up its aerial assaults on Ukrainian ports critical to the world’s food supply, as the White House warned that the Kremlin has mined sea routes and might be setting the stage for attacks on commercial transport ships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Netflix’s Strike Defense Is Strong. It May Have Some Cracks Anyway.
description: The company is best suited among media giants to cope with the Hollywood shutdown. But a lengthy strike by writers and actors will eventually cause damage.
content: Netflix’s latest financial report yesterday had a lot to impress shareholders, including renewed subscriber growth and expectations of better cash flow, thanks to strike-enabled cutbacks in content spending.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: It’s By-election Day in the U.K. What Does That Mean?
description: Three seats in Parliament recently occupied by Conservatives are up for grabs in an election that may show which way the political winds are blowing.
content: One of the last things Britain’s prime minister, Rishi Sunak, needs right now, while he’s trailing in the opinion polls as the economy stalls, is a test of his electoral popularity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir and Hari Kumar
title: Landslide Kills at Least 10 in Western India
description: More than 100 more people were feared to be trapped under debris, as torrential monsoon rainfall continued to pummel the country.
content: A landslide triggered by torrential rains in the western Indian state of Maharashtra killed at least 10 people late Wednesday night, with more than 100 feared trapped under debris, as rescue workers battled difficult terrain and heavy downpours searching for survivors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: The two host nations are embracing their moment.
description: Australia, a sports-mad nation with a long tradition of champions in other sports, has never been past the round of 16 at the Women’s World Cup. New Zealand, a rugby nation accustomed to life on the fringes of the biggest events in sports, has never won a game in the tournament.
content: Australia, a sports-mad nation with a long tradition of champions in other sports, has never been past the round of 16 at the Women’s World Cup. New Zealand, a rugby nation accustomed to life on the fringes of the biggest events in sports, has never won a game in the tournament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Texas to Leave Voting Integrity Group Targeted by Right-Wing Attacks
description: The nonprofit group ERIC, which helps maintain accurate voter rolls, was once widely embraced. But since last year, Trump allies have pushed red states to reject it.
content: Texas said on Thursday that it would drop out of a bipartisan voter integrity group that once included about three dozen states, further destabilizing an organization that has been undermined by right-wing attacks and defections by Republican-led members.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: Summer Pastas for Summer Zodiac Signs
description: Happy birthday and happy pastas to you, Cancers, Leos and Virgos.
content: Ask any millennials born in July about their birthday and they’ll recount a childhood colored by anxieties about the day: no classroom cupcakes, no gift-wrapped locker and an ever-present fear that no one will come to your party because everyone is at sleep-away camp or the beach or their grandma’s house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Anchor Workers Want to Save Their Brewery by Buying It
description: About 39 unionized workers, who represent two-thirds of the brewery’s employees, agreed to pursue a bid to run it as a co-op, a union official said.
content: Unionized workers at Anchor Brewing Company, the oldest craft brewer in the United States, want to buy the 127-year-old company and run it as a co-op to save it from shutting down, a union official said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: AMC Theater Chain to Stop Charging for Better Seats
description: The contentious initiative will be abandoned next month, though the company will roll out a new one involving lounge-style seating in the front rows.
content: AMC is abandoning plans to charge more for movie seats depending on their location. But higher prices for center-middle seats at theaters where AMC has been testing the concept will remain in effect this weekend, when “Barbie” and “Oppenheimer” are expected to draw significant crowds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Beware the New American Triumphalism
description: Our economy has done well lately. Don’t become complacent.
content: U.S. economic news has been pretty good lately. Our job market has fully recovered from Covid and then some, defying predictions of permanent “scarring” from pandemic disruptions. Inflation is down, falling faster than in any other large advanced economy. At the same time, economic trouble seems to abound abroad, notably in China, where the end of the “zero Covid” policy hasn’t brought the expected economic surge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: ‘And Just Like That …’ Episode 6 Fashion: No Way to Dress for the Weather
description: In the new episode, Carrie and her friends brave the streets of New York City in a blizzard.
content: This article contains spoilers for Episode 6 of the second season of “And Just Like That …”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Guo
title: House Overwhelmingly Passes Bill to Improve Air Travel
description: The House cleared away a number of potential sticking points that had threatened to hold up the bill to reauthorize the Federal Aviation Administration. It goes next to the Senate.
content: The House on Thursday overwhelmingly passed bipartisan legislation to reauthorize the Federal Aviation Administration for the next half-decade, moving at a time of growing dysfunction and disruption in the system to make a number of changes that affect passengers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Senison
title: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and the Bronx
description: This week’s properties are on the Upper East Side, in the East Village and Spuyten Duyvil.
content: A one-bedroom, one-bath, 950-square-foot apartment with an open living/dining area, a galley kitchen with a pantry, a king-size bedroom, ample closets and through-the-wall air-conditioning on the seventh floor of a 13-story doorman building with a courtyard, gym, bike room, live-in superintendent, basement storage cases and shared laundry and a public parking garage. Sheila Starr, Berkshire Hathaway HomeServices, 917-557-1173; bhhsnyproperties.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: New York to Pay $13 Million Over Police Actions at George Floyd Protests
description: The city settled a major class-action lawsuit that said unlawful police tactics had violated the rights of more than 1,000 people who protested after Mr. Floyd’s killing.
content: On the evening of June 2, 2020, Sabrina Zurkuhlen joined a protest march on the West Side Highway that was spurred by the killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis eight days earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yiwen Lu
title: An A.I. Supercomputer Whirs to Life, Powered by Giant Computer Chips
description: The new supercomputer, made by the Silicon Valley start-up Cerebras, was unveiled as the A.I. boom drives demand for chips and computing power.
content: Inside a cavernous room this week in a one-story building in Santa Clara, Calif., six-and-a-half-foot-tall machines whirred behind white cabinets. The machines made up a new supercomputer that had become operational just last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani
title: For Europe’s Older Population, Heat Is the New Covid
description: Scorching temperatures have threatened the health of the elderly and pushed them inside, while governments are trying to take extraordinary steps to protect them.
content: As a light, hot breeze blew through her living room and her gray hair, Donata Grillo, a 75-year-old cancer survivor with a pacemaker and serious sight problems, sat next to her balcony, a damp sponge on her lap.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: petulance
description: This word has appeared in seven articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word petulance has appeared in seven articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 5 in “John McEnroe Gets His Revenge” by Matthew Futterman:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: ‘Glitch: The Rise & Fall of HQ Trivia’ Review: Grandiose Pursuits
description: The fraught behind-the-scenes drama of the short-lived quiz game app is chronicled in this smart, briskly funny documentary.
content: “Glitch: The Rise & Fall of HQ Trivia,” by the director Salima Koroma, seems at first glance like many other recent rise-and-fall narratives, which usually describe, in sensational terms, the hubristic ascent and Icarian plunge of Silicon Valley start-ups, social media platforms, cellphone manufacturers and even video game developers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: N.F.L. Approves $6 Billion Deal for Washington Commanders, and Dan Snyder’s Exit
description: Josh Harris will buy the Washington franchise for a record $6.05 billion from Snyder, who faced sexual harassment allegations, decades of losing and public pressure to change the team’s name and logo.
content: Owners of the N.F.L.’s 31 other teams unanimously approved the sale of the Washington Commanders to a group led by Josh Harris, the private equity billionaire, who agreed to pay a record $6.05 billion to Daniel Snyder, the scandal-plagued owner of the team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Hacking of Government Email Was Traditional Espionage, Official Says
description: The hackers penetrated the accounts of senior State Department officials, including the U.S. ambassador to China.
content: The hack of Microsoft’s cloud that resulted in the compromise of government emails was an example of a traditional espionage threat, a senior National Security Agency official said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chavi Karkowsky
title: The Overlooked Reason Our Health Care System Crushes Patients
description: A quarter of insured adults report delayed or missed medical care because of administrative tasks.
content: Several years ago, I was called urgently to our small obstetric triage unit because a pregnant patient was very sick. At the beginning of her third trimester, she had come in with back pain and a 103-degree fever. Her heart was racing, her blood pressure was dangerously low, and her oxygen levels were barely normal. In sentences broken by gasps for air, she told us her belly was tightening every few minutes — painful contractions, three months before their time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Trump Seeks U.A.W.’s Support as the Union Wavers on Backing Biden
description: A video from the former president attacked electric vehicles, predicting the demise of the American automotive industry.
content: Donald J. Trump, seeing an opening with organized labor, appealed on Thursday for an endorsement from the United Auto Workers for his White House bid and said only his return to the presidency could save the automotive industry from President Biden’s “ridiculous Green New Deal crusade.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: Why Heat Waves Are Deepening China’s Addiction to Coal
description: While pledging to reduce carbon emissions, the country is greatly increasing its use of the fossil fuel to generate electricity.
content: China has an answer to the heat waves now affecting much of the Northern Hemisphere: burn more coal to maintain a stable electricity supply for air-conditioning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: SPAC Tied to Trump’s Media Company Will Pay $18 Million to Regulators
description: Digital World will pay a penalty to the Securities and Exchange Commission to settle an investigation into its planned merger with Trump Media & Technology Group.
content: The Securities and Exchange Commission said on Thursday that it had reached a settlement with the cash-rich shell company that planned to merge with former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company, potentially paving the way for the much-delayed deal to proceed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: Survey of 30 U.S. Cities Shows Nearly 10 Percent Drop in Homicides in 2023
description: After a surge during the height of Covid, killings have fallen but remain well above prepandemic levels.
content: In 2020, amid the disruptions of the pandemic and the social upheaval following the police murder of George Floyd in Minneapolis,  the United States saw the largest increase in its homicide rate in modern history. Now, more than three years after the start of the pandemic, the country is on track to record one of its largest — if not the largest — annual declines in homicides, according to a report released on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum, Joseph Goldstein and Johnny Milano
title: The Polygon and the Avalanche: How the Gilgo Beach Suspect Was Found
description: As investigators spent years looking for a suspect, a key clue was buried in their files. Could they have solved the case years earlier?
content: They called it the polygon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Nebraska Teen Who Used Pills to End Pregnancy Gets 90 Days in Jail
description: Celeste Burgess, 19, and her mother, Jessica Burgess, 42, were charged last year after the police obtained their private Facebook messages.
content: A Nebraska teenager who used abortion pills to terminate her pregnancy was sentenced on Thursday to 90 days in jail after she pleaded guilty earlier this year to illegally concealing human remains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Investor Charged With Kidnapping ‘Crypto King’
description: Aiden Pleterski is accused of spending investors’ money on luxury cars and vacations before filing for bankruptcy, according to court records. Then he was kidnapped by one of his investors, police say.
content: Late one night in early December, Aiden Pleterski, a self-proclaimed “Crypto King,” was kidnapped, then beaten and tortured over three days, according to court records.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Listen: The Mysterious Woman Next Door, Tom Hanks Talks, Phoenix Heat Wave
description: Each week, we share the best of new audio journalism and storytelling.
content: Hey Audio fans,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Why the Mayor Could Lose Control of Rikers Island
description: It will be up to a judge to decide if an outside authority will run the troubled jails complex. She appears to be losing patience with the city.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. We’ll look at the possibility of a federal takeover of the troubled Rikers Island jail complex. We’ll also get details on transit fare increases that will take effect within a month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: China pushes back against U.S. climate pressure.
content: John Kerry, the U.S. climate envoy, had traveled to Beijing in hopes of persuading officials there to start reducing China’s carbon emissions on a faster timeline. But after three days of talks, Kerry emerged without any new agreements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivy Manners
title: Should You Hire a Bridal Stylist?
description: These fashion experts will not only help you find the perfect wedding day look, but also curate a collection of ensembles for related events.
content: When it came to dressing for her May 6 wedding, Ashley Oliver Thomas had trouble narrowing down the many options available, while at the same time navigating a new job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle, Ross Douthat, Carlos Lozada and Lydia Polgreen
title: 33 Reading Recommendations for Your Summer Vacation
description: Whether you’re into mysteries or the making of mob movies, we’ve got something for you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: Tornado Tears Through Pfizer’s N.C. Site, Threatening Crucial Drug Supplies
description: Extensive damage occurred at the company’s property in Rocky Mount, and many products used by hospitals appeared to have been affected. This could further exacerbate shortages.
content: A tornado caused extensive damage to a Pfizer drug manufacturing site in Rocky Mount, N.C., on Wednesday, threatening critical supplies for hospitals across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: Is It Safe to Go Outside? How to Navigate This Cruel Summer.
description: Heat, flooding and wildfire smoke have made for treacherous conditions. Use this guide to determine when it’s safe to head out and when you should stay home.
content: Excessive rain and flooding in the Northeast, a dangerous heat wave with triple-digit temperatures across the South, West and Midwest, and smoke from wildfires in Canada have all come together to make this a summer of weather extremes in the United States, in which going outside can be riddled with perils.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Fear the Night’ Review: Party Raid
description: Neil LaBute’s new thriller, starring Maggie Q, feels stapled together from a pile of threadbare tropes.
content: One rarely roots for the bad guys in a home-invasion shocker, but, as the majority of the victims in Neil LaBute’s “Fear the Night” are either insufferably stupid or gratingly snippy, their survival is perhaps not the priority it ought to be.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Kissinger, 100, Gets Accolades in China Visits
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, July 20, 2023
content: “American policy toward China needs Kissinger-style diplomatic wisdom, and Nixon-style political bravery.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Should No Labels Run a Presidential Candidate?
description: Readers discuss the likely impact and the challenges of its possible third-party bid. Also: Oppenheimer’s lessons; animal disease outbreaks; wedding car cans.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Pierson, Vivian Wang and Edward Wong
title: Frustrated by Biden, China Courts ‘Old Friends’ Like Kissinger
description: In meeting with Henry Kissinger, China’s leader, Xi Jinping, is turning to American contacts outside the Biden administration to try to influence Washington’s thinking on China.
content: The red carpet welcome in Beijing for Henry A. Kissinger, the 100-year-old former secretary of state, included China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, telling him that “the Chinese people will always remember you.” It featured praise from China’s top diplomat for his wisdom. And it involved a meeting with the Chinese defense minister, who has rebuffed multiple requests to engage with his American counterpart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Stephen Curry: Underrated’ Review: Court Transcript
description: Initially considered too short and too scrawny, Curry went on to be an N.B.A. superstar. But there’s little that feels fresh or spontaneous in this earnest portrait.
content: Toggling between time frames, the earnest documentary “Stephen Curry: Underrated” portrays Stephen Curry, the Golden State Warrior routinely described as the greatest shooter in the history of the N.B.A., as an underdog during at least two crucial points in his career.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: From global warming to a reality show set on Mars, and from “My Hijacking” to “My Murder,” we bring you an eclectic selection of recommended books this week. In fiction, Gina Apostol’s novel “La Tercera” braids a mother-daughter story with a history of the Philippines, Deborah Willis’s “Girlfriend on Mars” imagines the above-mentioned reality show and Katie Williams’s “My Murder” brings its heroine back from the dead. In nonfiction, we recommend Jeff Goodell’s study of climate change, along with a biography of the extended Shakur family and a handful of memoirs covering everything from war reporting to a very public gender transition. Happy reading.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Kugel
title: Help! I Signed Up for a $4,800 Bird-Watching Trip but the Company Shut Down.
description: A family’s dream of seeing a rare warbler was dashed when Bird Watcher’s Digest collapsed. What happens when a tour operator goes under?
content: In 2021, my husband, my sister and I signed up for a five-day Tremendous Tawas Lake Huron tour run by Pardson, the Ohio company that publishes Bird Watcher’s Digest magazine. We paid almost $4,800 in all. The tour was canceled because of Covid that year, but we were so eager to see the rare Kirtland’s warbler that we accepted a credit. Shortly before the rescheduled trip was to leave in May 2022, the company emailed to tell us it was going out of business, and someone would contact us about a refund. No one did, but through my own efforts I got in touch with Jack Harris, the receiver responsible for the dissolution of Pardson. He told me the only way to get my money back would be through my credit card. But American Express said I was too late. Can you help? Paige, Atlanta
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: When It Comes to Death, Hadley Vlahos Tells It Like It Is
description: A new book by a hospice nurse helps readers wrap their minds around — and perhaps make peace with — the great unknown.
content: Ask enough newly minted best-selling authors to describe how their books were born and you’ll notice a trend: “It was March of 2020” is the new “Once upon a time.” In the annals of literary history, we have now arrived at the chapter in which the pandemic is part of most origin stories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Is This the End of the Red Carpet?
description: The actor’s strike could have far-reaching implications for how we watch and consume fashion.
content: At first it seemed impossible to imagine: No more red carpets! No more photos of movie stars and names to watch in fabulous gowns blanketing the internet. Could “Oppenheimer” and “Barbie” be the last gasp of that marketing Valhalla of fashion and film that was the modern premiere — at least for the foreseeable future?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: Review: ‘Minx’ Returns, Confident and Fully Exposed
description: Saved from cancellation, the porn-mag comedy is still a chaotic ride, but its ideas are more than skin-deep.
content: “This feels like the beginning of something,” Joyce Prigger (Ophelia Lovibond) says in Season 2 of “Minx.” She’s referring to the early ’70s, when America was rethinking gender roles and sexual rules, creating an opening for her to start the feminist porn magazine that gives the comedy its title.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: U.S. Investigating Why Delta Passengers Were Kept on Plane in Extreme Heat
description: The flight, from Las Vegas to Atlanta, was stalled at Harry Reid International Airport, leaving passengers sweltering in triple-digit temperatures, the department said.
content: The U.S. Department of Transportation said Thursday that it was investigating why passengers on a Delta Air Lines flight had been left to swelter for hours in triple-digit temperatures while the plane waited on the tarmac at a Las Vegas airport on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Europe Pushed Tunisia to Keep Migrants Away. The Result Is Harsh.
description: Tunisia has pushed African migrants to scorching no-man’s lands along its borders with little food and water. Under a deal with the European Union, Tunisia agreed to tighten border controls in exchange for aid.
content: For nearly three weeks now, more than 1,000 men, women and children from Africa have been clinging to survival in the no-man’s lands at Tunisia’s borders. A few scrubby trees offer fitful shade, videos taken by migrants show, and border guards from neighboring Libya and Tunisian aid workers occasionally drop off water and a bit of bread.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., Insisting He Is Not a Bigot, Says Opponents Seek to Silence Him
description: At a hearing convened by House Republicans, the Democratic presidential candidate defended himself against charges of racism and antisemitism.
content: The Democratic presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr. came to Capitol Hill on Thursday and pointedly declared that he is neither an antisemite nor a racist, while giving a fiery defense of free speech and accusing the Biden administration and his political opponents of trying to silence him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Trachta
title: ‘And Just Like That …’ Season 2, Episode 6 Recap: Hey Stranger
description: In an episode with multiple explicit callbacks to the original series, Charlotte sets a progressive example and Miranda confronts painful consequences.
content: The O.G.s know this isn’t the first time Carrie has fanned old flames with Aidan via email. Way back in Season 4 of the original series, Carrie created her first ever email address (shoegal@aol.com!) solely for the ability to reach out to Aidan post-breakup in some way other than the phone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr
title: Best Place for A.I. Jobs (New Report Says) Won’t Surprise You
description: Brookings Institution researchers found that San Francisco and San Jose, Calif., dominate job listings for generative A.I. work, potentially solidifying their control of the tech industry.
content: The San Francisco Bay Area has ruled the technology industry for decades, from the early days of personal computers to the social media boom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: What Do You Call a German Siesta? An Answer to the Europe Heat, Some Say.
description: The siesta, a sacred afternoon break in Spain, was once mocked as lazy. But now, countries like Germany, which were among the siesta haters, are taking another look.
content: A decade ago, in the wake of a financial crisis, Spain’s sacred siesta seemed to be under serious threat. Criticism was mounting across Europe that Spain’s sluggish economy resulted, in part, from its long midday break. Worried about being stereotyped as a sleepy, lazy country, Spain pledged to abolish the siesta to increase productivity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corey Kilgannon and Nate Schweber
title: Gilgo Beach Suspect’s House Becomes a Macabre Tourist Attraction
description: On Long Island, the fascinated and obsessed come to gawk at the house where the suspect lived. Some bring the children.
content: Scarlett Fascetti approached the dilapidated red house as if it were a shrine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai and Raja Abdulrahim
title: Protesters Angry Over Quran Burning Storm Swedish Embassy in Baghdad
description: The demonstrators, responding to a protest in Stockholm last month and ahead of one on Thursday, set fire to parts of the building.
content: Hundreds of protesters stormed the Swedish Embassy in Baghdad early Thursday and set fire to parts of it ahead of a demonstration outside the Iraqi Embassy in Sweden, where recent Quran burnings have inflamed anger in the Muslim world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Delger Erdenesanaa
title: June Was Earth’s Hottest on Record. August May Bring More of the Same.
description: In its monthly call, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Adminstration analyzed how June’s temperatures stacked up and said it expects August to continue the trend.
content: Last month was the planet’s warmest June since global temperature record-keeping began in 1850, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said in its monthly climate update on Thursday. The agency also predicts unusually hot temperatures will occur in most of the United States, almost everywhere except the northern Great Plains, during August.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mattie Kahn
title: Gretchen Whitmer Would Like You to Meet ‘Governor Barbie’
description: It’s part of a social media stunt by the pink-loving politician. But does it represent a shift for women in politics?
content: The politician is having a busy week. She has events at the Capitol and an important bill to sign into law. Like her namesake, who calls the shade her “power color,” she wears a hot pink pantsuit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles and Manuela Andreoni
title: How Extreme Heat Affects Workers and the Economy
description: “It drains your brain. It slows your cognitive function. You’re overwhelmed.”
content: Linda Ressler is an airplane cabin cleaner at the airport in Phoenix, where the temperature has reached or surpassed 110 degrees Fahrenheit for 20 days in a row and counting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Names Old and New Top British Open Leaderboard
description: Conditions were calm at Royal Liverpool as the final men’s golf major of the year began. Don’t expect them to stay that way.
content: A strategy for winning one of golf’s major championships only rarely looks like this: Find your flight canceled and the next one delayed, walk about a half-mile to passport control, endure a grinding wait at baggage claim less than 48 hours before the tournament’s first tee times and stare down jet lag.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Our TV critic recommends a snappy new comedy, a grounded drama and an absurd spin on a postapocalyptic tale.
content: ‘Praise Petey’
source.name: The New York Times

title: Richard Russo Misses the Purity of Childhood Reading
description: “When you become a writer, you inevitably lose your innocence as a reader,” says the Pulitzer-winning novelist, whose new book is “Somebody’s Fool.” “It’s like being given the underground tour of Disney World. Some of the magic dissipates.”
content: What books are on your night stand?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis Overbye
title: Christopher Nolan and the Contradictions of J. Robert Oppenheimer
description: The biopic director argues that the physicist who oversaw creation of the atomic bomb was both the most important person who ever lived and hopelessly naïve.
content: With the biopic “Oppenheimer,” due July 21, the writer-director Christopher Nolan, known for brain-twisting films like “Interstellar” and “Inception,” addresses an old childhood dread — one based not on science fiction but on real science, namely the threat of thermonuclear war and human annihilation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Belarus Says Wagner Fighters are Training Troops on the Polish Border
description: The Belarusian Defense Ministry said the country’s special operations units were jointly training with Wagner at a military range near the city of Brest.
content: The Belarusian Defense Ministry said on Thursday that mercenaries from the Wagner group were training troops on the border with Poland, a statement that was likely to increase tensions in an area where fears of conflict are already high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Australia’s New Queen
description: Sam Kerr is the face of the World Cup. She has the weight of a nation on her shoulders. She does not seem to have noticed.
content: Sam Kerr’s tone barely shifted. She had not, she said, had time to think about it yet. She had put it to the back of her mind. She had other things on which to focus her attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryce Covert
title: Don’t Let Inflation Bury the Memory of a Government Triumph
description: We got our economic response to the coronavirus right. Why would we let go of that success?
content: The recession caused by the Covid-19 pandemic was the shortest on record, thanks to rapid, robust and bipartisan congressional action. It took just over two years to regain all of the jobs lost — hard to fathom given that more than six million people filed unemployment insurance claims in one week at the end of March 2020. Americans were made whole by their government, which staved off what otherwise would have been mass financial suffering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on What to Call a Subway Line
description: A native New Yorker struggles with her boyfriend’s choice to refer to them by their colors.
content: Leah writes: My boyfriend, Matt, refers to subway lines by color. Instead of “the A train,” he calls it “the blue line.” This embarrasses me as a native New Yorker. It also doesn’t work: The A, C and E are all blue but stop at different places.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Obstruction Law Cited by Prosecutors in Trump Case Has Drawn Challenges
description: Hundreds of Jan. 6 rioters have been charged with obstruction of an official proceeding, but the charge, which could be applied to former President Donald J. Trump, has come under scrutiny.
content: Well before the prosecutors investigating Donald J. Trump’s efforts to overturn the 2020 election laid out for him three laws that could be the basis for an indictment, one of the statutes, covering obstruction of an official proceeding, had already been used against — and challenged by — scores of rioters who took part in the storming of the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Union for Broadway Crew Members Reaches Tentative Deal, Averting Strike
description: The agreement would cover a subset of workers, including about 1,500 stagehands, hairdressers and other crew members on Broadway and in touring productions.
content: The union representing a segment of Broadway crew members reached a tentative agreement for a new contract with theater owners just as its members were voting on whether to authorize a potential strike, the organizations announced Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Roald Dahl Museum Calls Author’s Racism ‘Undeniable and Indelible’
description: A museum in England devoted to the best-selling children’s author, who died in 1990, condemned his antisemitic views.
content: A museum devoted to Roald Dahl, the best-selling British author, has condemned his antisemitic views and said his racism was “undeniable and indelible.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana G. Smith
title: Heat Affects Older People More. Here’s How to Stay Safe.
description: If you’re over 65, it’s important to take high temperatures seriously.
content: We are experiencing the hottest days in history. Heat waves have blanketed the Northern Hemisphere this week, with temperatures reaching 100 degrees Fahrenheit on three continents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Bawaal’ Review: Getting Some Perspective
description: In this Bollywood production, a narcissistic history teacher reconnects with his wife on a trip through Europe.
content: “Bawaal” is a sensationally absurd Bollywood production that tells a simple moral story about what it means to be a Real Man. Directed by Nitesh Tiwari (“Dangal”), this globe-trotting romance is, like many Bollywood movies, willfully over the top. But this one’s not very fun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Tesla Wants to Double the Size of Its European Assembly Plant
description: The electric automaker wants to produce a million cars a year at its plant near Berlin, a step that would make it Europe’s largest car factory.
content: Tesla wants to double the production capacity of its assembly plant outside Berlin to one million electric vehicles a year, a move that would make it the largest car plant in Europe at a time when German automakers are struggling to keep pace in the transition to electric vehicles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay, Michael D. Shear and Dan Simmons
title: Status of Soldier Who Entered North Korea Remains Unknown, U.S. Says
description: The Biden administration is trying to determine Pvt. Travis T. King’s condition and location.
content: U.S. officials said Thursday that they had no information on the whereabouts or condition of an Army soldier who crossed into North Korea without authorization and had not spoken to North Korean authorities about the incident.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: What to Expect From Wildfire Season in California This Year
description: A wet winter may have delayed the state’s fire season, but it could ultimately make the blazes worse.
content: Compared with recent years, the 2023 fire season in California is off to a slow start.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘How to Dance in Ohio,’ a Musical, Plans a Fall Broadway Opening
description: A teenage ritual takes on deeper significance as a setting where autistic young people can blossom — and exercise their social skills along the way.
content: “How to Dance in Ohio,” a poignant new musical about a group of young autistic adults gearing up for a spring dance, will open on Broadway late this year, with a cast of seven autistic performers playing the central roles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly and Marisa Schwartz Taylor
title: A Year of Upheaval on Abortion’s Front Lines
description: A Supreme Court decision created a 50-state patchwork of differing abortion laws. An eclectic network of volunteers and organizations has tried to fill the gaps in health care and support.
content: A Supreme Court decision created a 50-state patchwork of differing abortion laws. An eclectic network of volunteers and organizations has tried to fill the gaps in health care and support.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Aspartame: What to Know
source.name: The New York Times

title: GWS-MISSION-IMPOSSIBLE
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: With Just a 5 Percent Down Payment, What Would $650,000 Buy in Bed-Stuy?
description: Miranda Haymon, a theater director and writer, was able to make (and save) money during the pandemic. How far would it go in Brooklyn in late 2022?
content: Miranda Haymon, a theater director and writer, was able to make (and save) money during the pandemic. How far would it go in Brooklyn in late 2022?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Al Qasimi and Sara Aridi
title: For Young Arab Americans in Michigan, the Hookah Lounge Feels like Home
description: A new generation of immigrants, refugees and their descendants is finding a sense of connection and community around the shisha pipe.
content: A new generation of immigrants, refugees and their descendants is finding a sense of connection and community around the shisha pipe.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the Full Report on the Investigation Into Dan Snyder
description: The N.F.L. spent 17 months looking into allegations of widespread sexual harassment against executives of the Washington Commanders, as well as claims of financial improprieties.
content: The N.F.L. spent 17 months looking into allegations of widespread sexual harassment against executives of the Washington Commanders, as well as claims of financial improprieties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ingrid K. Williams
title: 36 Hours in Copenhagen
description: Famous for its design, food and dedication to sustainability, the Danish capital is celebrating its architecture with a yearlong slate of events and exhibitions.
content: Famous for its design, food and dedication to sustainability, the Danish capital is celebrating its architecture with a yearlong slate of events and exhibitions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Protesters in Baghdad Storm Swedish Embassy
description: The demonstrators, angry over Quran burnings in Sweden, protested throughout the night, setting part of the embassy on fire.
content: The demonstrators, angry over Quran burnings in Sweden, protested throughout the night, setting part of the embassy on fire.
source.name: The New York Times
